feed.title: Katsu’s World
feed.subtitle: Hello! I'm Katsu, and this is my new website. I'll just be putting random stuff here like programs and videos I make. This page isn't finished (and won't be for a while) so expect a lot of updates. Also, I'm not going to put an email address here for a while. Enjoy!

entry.title: A proper introduction
entry.content:
Hi, I’m back after a while! I realized I never actually introduced myself, so here we are. My name is Katsu, and I write this website. This is like my 5th try at making a website, 2 of them being suspended my my web host because no one went to them, and the other 2 still up, those 2 being this one and this one. There’s nothing really left to say, so goodbye!

-Katsu

entry.title: I made an archive of software! (woo, first blog post!)

link.title: I made an archive of software! (woo, first blog post!)

entry.content:
Hey! This is my first post, so it might sound really… unprofessional. Sorry. But anyway, back to regularly scheduled programming. I made a software archive!

What does that mean?

It’s basically just a folder of software that’s either extremely hard to find or just not available anymore, like Flash Player. I found most of this by going though old download pages on the Internet Archive then downloading the files, then putting the files on here. It’s a complicated process, but at least it’s simpler now because of this. I believe this qualifies as fair use, so this is legal. I’m not claiming to own any of this software. I hope you like the archive.

Oh, yeah, and here’s the link.

Bye!

-Katsu
entry.summary: Hey! This is my first post, so it might sound really… unprofessional. Sorry. But anyway, back to regularly scheduled programming. I made a software archive!

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll! (default Jekyll blog post)

link.title: Welcome to Jekyll! (default Jekyll blog post)

entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
